    Certainly! Here's the converted code with the Three.js logic integrated into your Splash component using @react-three/fiber:

    jsx
    import React, { useRef, useEffect } from 'react';
import { Canvas, useFrame } from '@react-three/fiber';
import { GLTFLoader } from 'three/examples/jsm/loaders/GLTFLoader';
import * as THREE from 'three';

function GLTFModel() {
  const gltfRef = useRef();
  const gltf = useLoader(GLTFLoader, '/SK_raccoon_anim5.gltf');

  return <primitive object={gltf.scene} ref={gltfRef} />;
}

function ThreeScene() {
  const scene = new THREE.Scene();
  scene.fog = new THREE.Fog(0x000000, 8, 13);

  const camera = new THREE.PerspectiveCamera(75, window.innerWidth / window.innerHeight, 0.1, 20);
  camera.position.x = -1;
  camera.position.y = 0.8;
  camera.position.z = -4;

  const webglRenderer = new THREE.WebGLRenderer({
    antialias: true
  });
  webglRenderer.shadowMap.enabled = true;
  webglRenderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
  webglRenderer.setClearColor(0x000000);
  webglRenderer.setPixelRatio(window.devicePixelRatio);
  document.body.appendChild(webglRenderer.domElement);

  const controls = new THREE.OrbitControls(camera, webglRenderer.domElement);

  const linesGeom1 = new THREE.BufferGeometry();
  const linesGeom2 = new THREE.BufferGeometry();
  const linesGeom3 = new THREE.BufferGeometry();
  const linesMatWhite = new THREE.LineBasicMaterial({ color: 0xffffff });
  const linesMatOrange = new THREE.LineBasicMaterial({ color: 0xfb8c00 });
  const linesMatBrown = new THREE.LineBasicMaterial({ color: 0x4d3227 });
  const line1 = new THREE.LineSegments(linesGeom1, linesMatWhite);
  scene.add(line1);
  const line2 = new THREE.LineSegments(linesGeom2, linesMatOrange);
  scene.add(line2);
  const line3 = new THREE.LineSegments(linesGeom3, linesMatBrown);
  scene.add(line3);

  const geometry = new THREE.PlaneGeometry(30, 30);
  const material2 = new THREE.ShadowMaterial({
    color: 0x111111,
    side: 2
  });
  const plane = new THREE.Mesh(geometry, material2);
  plane.rotation.x = Math.PI / 2;
  plane.position.y = -1.6;
  plane.receiveShadow = true;
  scene.add(plane);

  const light = new THREE.DirectionalLight(0xffffff, 1, 100);
  light.position.set(0.2, 0.5, -1);
  light.castShadow = true;
  light.shadow.mapSize.width = 2048;
  light.shadow.mapSize.height = 2048;
  light.shadow.radius = 8;
  scene.add(light);

  const pointsWhite = [];
  const pointsBrown = [];
  const pointsOrange = [];

  useEffect(() => {
    const loader = new THREE.OBJLoader();
    loader.load(
      'https://assets.codepen.io/127738/fox_low_poly.obj',
      function (obj) {
        scene.add(obj);
        obj.children[0].material[0].shininess = 0;
        obj.children[0].material[1].shininess = 0;
        obj.children[0].material[2].shininess = 0;
        obj.children[0].castShadow = true;
        const modifier = new THREE.SubdivisionModifier(2, false);

        const smooth = modifier.modify(obj.children[0].geometry);
        const lol = new THREE.BufferGeometry();
        lol.fromGeometry(smooth);
        obj.children[0].geometry = lol;
        const colors = [];
        obj.children[0].geometry.groups.forEach((g, index) => {
          for (let i = 0; i < g.count; i++) {
            if (index === 0) colors.push(1, 0, 0);
            if (index === 1) colors.push(0, 1, 0);
            if (index === 2) colors.push(0, 0, 1);
          }
        });
        obj.children[0].geometry.setAttribute(
          'color',
          new THREE.BufferAttribute(new Float32Array(colors), 3)
        );

        const sampler = new THREE.MeshSurfaceSampler(obj.children[0]).build();
        const p1 = new THREE.Vector3();
        const normal = new THREE.Vector3();
        const color = new THREE.Color();
        for (let i = 0; i < 50000; i++) {
          sampler.sample(p1, normal, color);
          normal.multiplyScalar(Math.random() * 0.04 + 0.02);
          let _p = p1.clone();
          _p._x = _p.x;
          _p._y = _p.y;
          _p._z = _p.z;
          _p.normal = normal.clone();
          let _p2 = p1.clone().add(normal);
          _p2._x = _p2.x;
          _p2._y = _p2.y;
          _p2._z = _p2.z;
          if (color.r) {
            pointsWhite.push(_p);
            pointsWhite.push(_p2);
          } else if (color.g) {
            pointsBrown.push(_p);
            pointsBrown.push(_p2);
          } else if (color.b) {
            pointsOrange.push(_p);
            pointsOrange.push(_p2);
          }
        }
        linesGeom1.setFromPoints(pointsWhite);
        linesGeom2.setFromPoints(pointsBrown);
        linesGeom3.setFromPoints(pointsOrange);

        obj.children[0].material.forEach((m) => {
          m.color = new THREE.Color(0x000000);
          m.emissive = new THREE.Color(0x000000);
          m.emissiveIntensity = 0.2;
          m.flatShading = 0.2;
        });

        requestAnimationFrame(render);
      }
    );
  }, []);

  const updateCoords = (arr, a, geom) => {
    for (let i = 0; i < arr.length; i += 2) {
      let p = arr[i];
      let p2 = arr[i + 1];

      let angle =
        noise.simplex3(p2._x * 0.4, p2._y * 0.4, p2._z * 0.4 + a * 0.00013) * 3.14;
      var xv = Math.cos(angle);
      var yv = Math.sin(angle);
      var v = p2.clone();
      v.cross(p.normal);
      var r1 = v.multiplyScalar(1.1 * xv);
      var r2 = v.multiplyScalar(1.1 * yv);
      p2.x = p2._x + r1.x + r2.x;
      p2.y = p2._y + r1.y + r2.y;
      p2.z = p2._z + r1.z + r2.z;
      geom.attributes.position.array[(i + 1) * 3] = p2.x;
      geom.attributes.position.array[(i + 1) * 3 + 1] = p2.y;
      geom.attributes.position.array[(i + 1) * 3 + 2] = p2.z;
    }
    geom.attributes.position.needsUpdate = true;
  };

  const render = (a) => {
    requestAnimationFrame(render);
    updateCoords(pointsWhite, a, linesGeom1);
    updateCoords(pointsOrange, a, linesGeom3);
    updateCoords(pointsBrown, a, linesGeom2);
    webglRenderer.render(scene, camera);
  };

  const onWindowResize = () => {
    camera.aspect = window.innerWidth / window.innerHeight;
    camera.updateProjectionMatrix();
    webglRenderer.setSize(window.innerWidth, window.innerHeight);
  };

  window.addEventListener('resize', onWindowResize, false);

  useEffect(() => {
    onWindowResize(); // Initialize size

    return () => {
      // Cleanup
      window.removeEventListener('resize', onWindowResize);
    };
  }, []);

  return null;
}

function Splash({ title, subtitle, header, buttons }) {
  return (
    <div className="splash-container">
      <Header title={title} subtitle={subtitle} header={header} buttons={buttons} />
      <div className="main-container">
        {/* <Navigation buttons={buttons} /> */}
        <div className="main-content">
          <Canvas shadowMap>
            <ThreeScene />
            <GLTFModel />
            <ambientLight intensity={0.5} />
            <directionalLight position={[5, 5, 5]} intensity={1} castShadow />
            <mesh receiveShadow>
              <planeGeometry args={[10, 10]} />
              <shadowMaterial transparent opacity={0.5} />
            </mesh>
          </Canvas>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  );
}

export default Splash;

    This code combines your GLTFModel and the Three.js scene into the Splash component using @react-three/fiber. Note that this example assumes you have already set up your project with the necessary dependencies and configurations for @react-three/fiber.

    Your code appears to be a React component that renders a three-dimensional scene using the @react-three/fiber library and the three library. The scene includes a 3D model loaded from a GLTF file, lines with different materials, a plane with a shadow, and lights.

    Here are a few suggestions for improvement:

    1. Organize Your Code: Consider organizing your code into smaller functions or components for better readability and maintainability.

    2. Optimize Imports: Remove any unnecessary imports to keep your code clean. For example, you're importing useFrame from @react-three/fiber, but it's not used in your code.

    3. Consistent Naming: Maintain consistent naming conventions throughout your code. For example, you have both line1, line2, and line3, and also linesGeom1, linesGeom2, and linesGeom3. Consider using a more systematic naming convention.

    4. Comments: Add comments to explain complex logic or important parts of your code. It will make it easier for others (or yourself) to understand the code later.

    5. Error Handling: Implement error handling for your asynchronous operations, such as the GLTF model loading. Currently, if there's an error during loading, it won't be handled.

    6. Responsive Design: Ensure that your three.js canvas and scene respond well to different screen sizes. You may need to adjust camera settings or use responsive design techniques.

    Remember to test your application across different browsers to ensure compatibility.

    Adding fur to a 3D model is a complex task and often involves using specialized techniques like fur shaders or particle systems. Unfortunately, the provided GLTF model doesn't seem to contain information about fur, and adding fur to an existing model involves more than just code adjustments.

    Here's a general approach you could take:

    1. Fur Material: First, you need a fur material. You can use a pre-existing fur shader or create a custom one. Three.js doesn't have built-in fur support, so you might need to explore third-party solutions or create your own shader.

    2. Geometry for Fur: Fur is often represented as a separate layer of geometry on top of the existing model. This can be achieved using additional geometry or a particle system. Each particle in the system represents a strand of fur.

    3. Particle System: Implement a particle system that generates and renders fur strands. Adjust the length, thickness, and density of the strands according to your preference.

    4. Shading: Apply the fur material to the fur geometry. The material should take lighting and shadowing into account to blend seamlessly with the underlying model.

    Here's a simplified example using a basic particle system (without proper shading for fur):

    javascript
    // Inside GLTFModel component

function FurParticles() {
  const furParticlesRef = useRef();

  // Initialize particle system and add it to the scene
  useEffect(() => {
    if (gltfRef.current) {
      const furMaterial = new THREE.MeshBasicMaterial({ color: 0x996633 }); // Customize fur color
      const furGeometry = new THREE.BufferGeometry(); // Implement proper geometry for fur

      // Populate furGeometry with vertices representing fur strands

      const furParticles = new THREE.Points(furGeometry, furMaterial);
      gltfRef.current.add(furParticlesRef.current);

      // Adjust the position and rotation of furParticles to align with the model
    }
  }, [gltfRef]);

  useFrame(() => {
    // Update particle positions and other dynamic effects here
  });

  return null; // FurParticles doesn't render anything directly
}

// Inside GLTFModel component, add FurParticles component
return (
  <>
    <primitive object={gltf.scene} ref={gltfRef} />
    <FurParticles />
  </>
);

    Certainly! Let's integrate the fur particle system into your existing GLTFModel component. Please note that the provided example is simplified, and you may need to customize it further for your specific needs.

    javascript
    import React, { useRef, useEffect } from 'react';
import { useLoader, useThree, useFrame } from '@react-three/fiber';
import { GLTFLoader } from 'three/examples/jsm/loaders/GLTFLoader';
import * as THREE from 'three';

function FurParticles({ parent }) {
  const furParticlesRef = useRef();

  // Initialize particle system and add it to the parent object
  useEffect(() => {
    if (parent) {
      const furMaterial = new THREE.PointsMaterial({ color: 0x996633, size: 0.02 });
      const furGeometry = new THREE.BufferGeometry();

      // Populate furGeometry with vertices representing fur strands

      const furParticles = new THREE.Points(furGeometry, furMaterial);
      parent.add(furParticlesRef.current);

      // Adjust the position and rotation of furParticles to align with the model
    }
  }, [parent]);

  useFrame(() => {
    // Update particle positions and other dynamic effects here
  });

  return null; // FurParticles doesn't render anything directly
}

function GLTFModel() {
  const gltfRef = useRef();
  const { camera } = useThree();

  // Adjust camera position to fit the object in view
  const setCameraPosition = () => {
    if (gltfRef.current) {
      const boundingBox = new THREE.Box3().setFromObject(gltfRef.current);
      const center = new THREE.Vector3();
      boundingBox.getCenter(center);
      const size = boundingBox.getSize(new THREE.Vector3());

      const maxDim = Math.max(size.x, size.y, size.z);
      const fov = camera.fov * (Math.PI / 180);
      let cameraZ = Math.abs((maxDim / 2) / Math.tan(fov / 2));

      // Adjust camera position based on the object's size
      camera.position.set(center.x, center.y, cameraZ + 0.41);
      camera.lookAt(center.x, center.y, 0);
    }
  };

  // Use frame to call setCameraPosition on each animation frame
  useFrame(() => {
    setCameraPosition();
    // Rotate the mesh
    if (gltfRef.current) {
      gltfRef.current.rotation.y += 0.01;
    }
    // Play animations if available
    if (gltfRef.current.animations && gltfRef.current.animations.length > 0) {
      gltfRef.current.mixer.update(0.01);
    }
  });

  return (
    <>
      <primitive object={gltfRef.current} ref={gltfRef} />
      <FurParticles parent={gltfRef.current} />
    </>
  );
}

export default GLTFModel;

    In this example, the FurParticles component is added to the GLTFModel component. It creates a particle system and attaches it to the provided parent object (in this case, the GLTF model). Adjust the particle system properties and appearance according to your preferences.

    Certainly! To add a fur effect to the loaded GLTF mesh in React Three Fiber, you can create a separate component for the fur particles and position them on the surface of the mesh. Here's an example:

    javascript
    import React, { useRef, useEffect } from 'react';
import { Canvas, useFrame, useLoader, useThree } from '@react-three/fiber';
import { GLTFLoader } from 'three/examples/jsm/loaders/GLTFLoader';
import * as THREE from 'three';

function FurParticles({ parent }) {
  const furParticlesRef = useRef();

  useEffect(() => {
    if (parent) {
      const furMaterial = new THREE.PointsMaterial({ color: 0x996633, size: 0.02 });
      const furGeometry = new THREE.BufferGeometry();

      // Populate furGeometry with vertices representing fur strands
      // You can use the vertices of the loaded mesh or generate custom fur geometry

      const furParticles = new THREE.Points(furGeometry, furMaterial);
      furParticlesRef.current = furParticles;
      parent.add(furParticles);

      // Adjust the position and rotation of furParticles to align with the model
      // For simplicity, set it to the same position as the model
      furParticles.position.set(0, 0, 0);
    }
  }, [parent]);

  useFrame(() => {
    // Update particle positions and other dynamic effects here
  });

  return null; // FurParticles doesn't render anything directly
}

function GLTFModel() {
  const gltfRef = useRef();
  const gltf = useLoader(GLTFLoader, '/SK_raccoon_anim5.gltf');
  const { camera } = useThree();

  const setCameraPosition = () => {
    if (gltfRef.current) {
      const boundingBox = new THREE.Box3().setFromObject(gltfRef.current);
      const center = new THREE.Vector3();
      boundingBox.getCenter(center);
      const size = boundingBox.getSize(new THREE.Vector3());

      const maxDim = Math.max(size.x, size.y, size.z);
      const fov = camera.fov * (Math.PI / 180);
      let cameraZ = Math.abs((maxDim / 2) / Math.tan(fov / 2));

      camera.position.set(center.x, center.y, cameraZ + 0.41);
      camera.lookAt(center.x, center.y, 0);
    }
  };

  useFrame(() => {
    setCameraPosition();
    if (gltfRef.current) {
      gltfRef.current.rotation.y += 0.01;
    }
    if (gltf.animations && gltf.animations.length > 0) {
      gltfRef.current.mixer.update(0.01);
    }
  });

  return (
    <>
      <primitive object={gltf.scene} ref={gltfRef} />
      {gltfRef.current && <FurParticles parent={gltfRef.current} />}
    </>
  );
}

function Splash({ title, subtitle, header, buttons }) {
  return (
    <div className="splash-container">
      {/* Header component */}
      <div className="main-container">
        <div className="main-content">
          <Canvas shadowMap>
            <ambientLight intensity={0.5} />
            <directionalLight position={[5, 5, 5]} intensity={1} castShadow />
            <GLTFModel />
            <mesh receiveShadow>
              <planeGeometry args={[10, 10]} />
              <shadowMaterial transparent opacity={0.5} />
            </mesh>
          </Canvas>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  );
}

export default Splash;

    In this example, the FurParticles component is responsible for creating and updating the fur particles. The GLTFModel component loads the GLTF model and positions it in the scene. The fur particles are added to the model's scene and positioned at the center of the model for simplicity. You may need to adjust the fur geometry and particle positioning based on your specific requirements.

    javascript
    import React, { useRef, useEffect } from 'react';
import { Canvas, useFrame, useLoader, useThree } from '@react-three/fiber';
import { GLTFLoader } from 'three/examples/jsm/loaders/GLTFLoader';
import * as THREE from 'three';

function FurParticles({ parent }) {
  const furParticlesRef = useRef();

  useEffect(() => {
    if (parent) {
      const furMaterial = new THREE.PointsMaterial({ color: 0x996633, size: 0.02 });
      const furGeometry = new THREE.BufferGeometry();

      // Populate furGeometry with vertices representing fur strands
      // For simplicity, you can use the vertices of the loaded mesh
      const vertices = parent.geometry.attributes.position.array;
      const positions = [];
      for (let i = 0; i < vertices.length; i += 3) {
        positions.push(vertices[i], vertices[i + 1], vertices[i + 2]);
      }

      furGeometry.setAttribute('position', new THREE.BufferAttribute(new Float32Array(positions), 3));

      const furParticles = new THREE.Points(furGeometry, furMaterial);
      furParticlesRef.current = furParticles;
      parent.add(furParticles);

      // Adjust the position and rotation of furParticles to align with the model
      // For simplicity, set it to the same position as the model
      furParticles.position.set(0, 0, 0);
    }
  }, [parent]);

  useFrame(() => {
    // Update particle positions and other dynamic effects here
  });

  return null; // FurParticles doesn't render anything directly
}

function GLTFModel() {
  const gltfRef = useRef();
  const gltf = useLoader(GLTFLoader, '/SK_raccoon_anim5.gltf');
  const { camera } = useThree();

  const setCameraPosition = () => {
    if (gltfRef.current) {
      const boundingBox = new THREE.Box3().setFromObject(gltfRef.current);
      const center = new THREE.Vector3();
      boundingBox.getCenter(center);
      const size = boundingBox.getSize(new THREE.Vector3());

      const maxDim = Math.max(size.x, size.y, size.z);
      const fov = camera.fov * (Math.PI / 180);
      let cameraZ = Math.abs((maxDim / 2) / Math.tan(fov / 2));

      camera.position.set(center.x, center.y, cameraZ + 0.41);
      camera.lookAt(center.x, center.y, 0);
    }
  };

  useFrame(() => {
    setCameraPosition();
    if (gltfRef.current) {
      gltfRef.current.rotation.y += 0.01;
    }
    if (gltf.animations && gltf.animations.length > 0) {
      gltfRef.current.mixer.update(0.01);
    }
  });

  return (
    <>
      <primitive object={gltf.scene} ref={gltfRef} />
      {gltfRef.current && <FurParticles parent={gltfRef.current} />}
    </>
  );
}

function Splash({ title, subtitle, header, buttons }) {
  return (
    <div className="splash-container">
      {/* Header component */}
      <div className="main-container">
        <div className="main-content">
          <Canvas shadowMap>
            <ambientLight intensity={0.5} />
            <directionalLight position={[5, 5, 5]} intensity={1} castShadow />
            <GLTFModel />
            <mesh receiveShadow>
              <planeGeometry args={[10, 10]} />
              <shadowMaterial transparent opacity={0.5} />
            </mesh>
          </Canvas>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  );
}

export default Splash;

    Now, the FurParticles component uses the vertices of the loaded mesh to populate the furGeometry. Adjustments may be needed based on the specific fur effect you want to achieve.
